items.item_details:
The Board of Trustees offers an opportunity for the public to address the Board in four sections of the agenda: on matters of concern about Closed Session items; on matters not appearing on the agenda; on action items contained in the Consent Agenda; and prior to voting on any item contained in the Action Agenda. Each speaker is encouraged to submit a comment card to the Board clerk in order to be recognized to speak.
	Per Board Policy, three minutes may be allotted to each speaker with a maximum of 30 minutes per subject. No action or discussion shall be undertaken on any public comments except that members of the Board or its staff may briefly respond to or ask a question for clarification regarding statements made or questions posed by persons addressing the Board under this agenda item.
	For information and disability access to materials, call 408-288-3136. Meetings are held in a location accessible to the disabled.

items.item_details:
The Board of Trustees will recognize Kordai Herring and Ramon Ramirez, two students from Evergreen Valley College, who became Lifetime Award Recipients of the President's Volunteer Service Award. The President's Volunteer Service Award is an initiative of the Corporation for the National and Community Service and is administered by the Point of Light Institute. Kordai Herring was recognized for his 5000 hours of volunteer service; Ramon Ramirez, for 4013.50 hours of volunteer service.
Background Information on the awards extracted from the Presidential Service Awards Website
America has a long and proud tradition of volunteer service. Now more than ever, volunteers are renewing their commitment to helping others and making new connections that bring us closer together as families, as neighbors, as communities, and as a Nation.
The President's Council on Service and Civic Participation (the Council) was established in 2003 to recognize the valuable contributions volunteers are making in our communities and encourage more people to serve. The Council created the President’s Volunteer Service Award program as a way to thank and honor Americans who, by their demonstrated commitment and example, inspire others to engage in volunteer service.
Recognizing and honoring volunteers sets a standard for service, encourages a sustained commitment to civic participation, and inspires others to make service a central part of their lives. The President’s Volunteer Service Award recognizes individuals, families, and groups that have achieved a certain standard – measured by the number of hours of service over a 12-month period or cumulative hours earned over the course of a lifetime.
To date, the President’s Council has partnered with more than 80  Leadership Organizations and more than 28,000 Certifying Organizations to bestow more than 1.5 million awards to the Nation's deserving volunteers.
Further information can be found on the link below:
http://www.presidentialserviceawards.gov/tg/pvsainfo/dspAboutAwards.cfm

Education Code 81655 stipulates that no contract is an enforceable obligation of the district until it has been ratified by the Board of Trustees. District policy adopted on April 10, 2007 establishes the authority of certain administrators to approve contracts under the bid limit prior to formal Board approval.  All contracts and purchase orders exceeding the bid limit (currently $78,500) should have prior board approval as a separate Board item.
	This consent item presents for Board approval:  all purchase orders for the period of time referenced on the attachments, which include all purchase orders for administratively-approved contracts exceeding $750, as well as any additional contracts that are not executed by way of purchase order as deemed appropriate to be added by purchasing.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees ratify the contracts.

The Fiscal Services Department has done an initial projection of cash flow needs for next fiscal year. In this analysis was factored the projected cost increases in the District budget with no anticipated increase in revenue, along with an assumption that the State will be delaying the General Apportionment payment for the month of June until July 2011. We anticipate projected deficit during the first, second, and third quarters of fiscal year 2010/2011.
 
Each year, many community colleges project negative cash flows in some months and must engage in temporary borrowing in order to ensure that funds are available to meet payroll and other expenditures. Fortunately, for many years, the California Community College League has coordinated an effort to pool the cash needs of these districts by issuing one debt instrument for all districts. This provides substantial savings in the cost of going to market with short-term debt instruments. The cost of these Tax Revenue and Anticipation Notes (TRANS) will be roughly $320,000 - $350,000 to the District, most of which will be offset by the short-term investment earnings that the District will earn while this money is deposited in the County's investment pool. The estimated expense to the General Fund after netting out investment income from the cost of the TRANS will be approximately $100,000.
Attachment A contains the resolution that the Board of Trustees must adopt in order for the District to participate in the pooled TRANS program.
